Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Thomas Fai is "Modeling and Simulation of Deformable Cells in Microfluidic Devices." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Chris Rycroft.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this work, mathematical models were developed of the red blood cell cytoskeleton and of the fluid dynamics of vesicle transport in neurons. The models of the red blood cell used biological imaging data obtained using a recently developed technique known as cryo-electron microscopy. We applied the mathematical theory of graphs to extract structural information from images, and then performed simulations to understand the consequences of different graph structures, such as those that occur in diseases associated with anemia.

A second mathematical model involved the fluid dynamics of vesicle transport inside of neurons. Membrane receptors are required to detect action potentials at the synapse and to allow neurons to communicate. These membrane receptors are trafficked to the synapse along flexible membraneous compartments by the action of molecular motors. In this project, we studied the fluid dynamics of how these compartments are transported into intriguingly-shaped structures at the synapse called dendritic spines. We found that the interaction between the shapes of the spines, together with the pushing and pulling of motors, gives rise to multiple stable solutions. This is biologically interesting because it shows how different behaviors can emerge spontaneously from identical systems, and allows us to speculate about why some connections between neurons become stronger while others atrophy over time.

Finally, this project involved the development of a general numerical method for accurately computing the fluid dynamics inside of complex geometries. The idea of this method is to combine a widely-used method (the immersed boundary method) for fluid-structure interaction problems, such as the ones described above, with an analytical model of films. We believe this method has the potential to overcome a key difficulty of the immersed boundary method that occurs when multiple structures come close to touching.
